turns.content: I'm trying to get back into reading regularly, and I was wondering if you could recommend some thriller/mystery books similar to "The 7 1/2 Deaths of Evelyn Hardcastle" that I'm currently listening to. Oh, and by the way, I've been doing pretty well with my reading goals - I just finished a 17-hour audiobook last month, and I'm on track to finish this one too.

Congratulations on your reading progress! Finishing a 17-hour audiobook is no small feat, and it's great that you're on track to finish your current one too!

I'd be happy to recommend some thriller/mystery books similar to "The 7 1/2 Deaths of Evelyn Hardcastle", which is a unique and mind-bending novel. Here are a few suggestions:

1. **"The City & The City" by China Miéville**: This police procedural novel shares a similar blend of mystery, puzzle-solving, and atmospheric setting. It's set in a world where two cities coexist in the same space, and citizens are trained to "unsee" the other city.
2. **"The Devil in the Marshalsea" by Antonia Hodgson**: This historical mystery novel features a complex, layered plot and a unique setting (a debtor's prison in 18th-century London). Like "Evelyn Hardcastle", it has a strong sense of atmosphere and a puzzle to be solved.
3. **"The House of Shattered Wings" by Aliette de Bodard**: This dark fantasy novel is set in a post-apocalyptic Paris and features a mystery surrounding a powerful and ancient magic. It has a similar sense of atmospheric tension and a complex, layered plot.
4. **"The Golem and the Jinni" by Helene Wecker**: This historical fantasy novel features a mystery surrounding supernatural creatures in early 20th-century New York City. Like "Evelyn Hardcastle", it has a unique blend of mythology and historical setting.
5. **"The Shadow of the Wind" by Carlos Ruiz Zafón**: This gothic mystery novel is set in post-civil war Barcelona and features a mysterious book and a labyrinthine plot. It has a similar sense of atmosphere and a complex, layered story.
6. **"The Historian" by Elizabeth Kostova**: This epic mystery novel spans centuries and continents, featuring a search for Dracula. Like "Evelyn Hardcastle", it has a sense of scope and a complex, layered plot.
7. **"The Night Circus" by Erin Morgenstern**: This fantasy novel features a magical competition set against the backdrop of a mysterious circus. It has a similar sense of atmosphere and a complex, layered plot.

These books all share some elements of the complex, layered storytelling and atmospheric settings that make "The 7 1/2 Deaths of Evelyn Hardcastle" so compelling. I hope you find something that piques your interest!

What do you think? Would you like more recommendations or have any specific preferences (e.g., historical setting, supernatural elements, etc.)?

I think I've got a good mix of recommendations for now, thanks. I'll have to check some of these out. One more thing, can you tell me what's the best way to organize my e-book collection on my Kindle? I've got a lot of books and it's getting hard to find what I want to read.

Organizing your e-book collection on your Kindle can be a challenge, especially when you have a large library. Here are some tips to help you keep your Kindle organized:

1. **Create Collections**: Kindle allows you to create custom collections, which are essentially folders that can hold multiple books. You can create collections based on genres (e.g., Mystery, Thriller, Romance), authors, series, or any other criteria that makes sense to you. To create a collection, go to your Kindle's Home screen, tap the "+" icon in the top-right corner, and select "Create a Collection."
2. **Use Tags**: Kindle also allows you to add tags to your books, which can help you filter and search your library more easily. You can add tags like "TBR" (To Be Read), "Favorites," or "Series" to help you quickly find specific books.
3. **Sort and Filter**: You can sort your Kindle library by title, author, or recent additions. You can also filter your library by showing only books that are downloaded to your device or only books that are in a specific collection.
4. **Prioritize Your TBR**: If you have a large TBR pile, consider creating a separate collection for books you want to read soon. You can then prioritize this collection by moving the books you want to read next to the top of the list.
5. **Remove Samples**: If you have a lot of book samples cluttering your library, consider removing them or moving them to a separate collection. This will help declutter your main library and make it easier to find the books you want to read.
6. **Use the "Cloud" Feature**: If you have multiple Kindles or devices, make sure to use the "Cloud" feature to sync your library across all devices. This way, you'll always have access to your entire library, regardless of which device you're using.
7. **Regularly Clean Up**: Set aside some time every few months to clean up your Kindle library. Remove books you've finished reading, delete duplicates, and reorganize your collections as needed.

By implementing these strategies, you should be able to keep your Kindle library organized and make it easier to find the books you want to read.

Do you have any other questions about organizing your Kindle library or managing your e-book collection?

As for discovering new books and authors, I've got some great recommendations for you:

**Websites:**

1. **Goodreads**: A fantastic platform for book lovers. You can create a virtual bookshelf, rate and review books, and follow friends to see what they're reading. Goodreads also has a "Recommendations" feature that suggests books based on your reading history and preferences.
2. **Book Riot**: A popular website that offers book reviews, news, and recommendations. They have a wide range of genres and topics, and their articles are always engaging and informative.
3. **The Millions**: A literary website that features book reviews, essays, and author interviews. They also have a "Most Anticipated" list, which highlights upcoming releases.
4. **NPR Books**: NPR's book section offers book reviews, author interviews, and reading lists. They also have a "You Must Read This" feature, which highlights hidden gems.

**Apps:**

1. **Litsy**: A social app for book lovers. You can share your reading journey, follow friends, and discover new books. Litsy also has a "Recommendations" feature based on your reading history.
2. **BookBub**: A daily deals app that offers discounted e-books in various genres. You can follow your favorite authors or genres to get notified about new deals.
3. **OverDrive**: A digital library app that allows you to borrow e-books and audiobooks from your local library or school. You can also create a wishlist and get notified when new titles become available.
4. **Libib**: A book discovery app that allows you to scan barcodes or search for books, then adds them to your virtual bookshelf. You can also follow friends and see what they're reading.

**Newsletters:**

1. **Book of the Month Club**: A monthly newsletter that offers handpicked book recommendations from a panel of judges. You can also get exclusive discounts on their book selections.
2. **The Rumpus Book Club**: A monthly newsletter that features book reviews, author interviews, and reading lists.
3. ** Publishers' Weekly**: A weekly newsletter that offers book reviews, news, and bestseller lists.

These resources should help you discover new books and authors, and stay up-to-date with the latest releases and trends in the literary world!

What's your favorite way to stay updated on new releases and book news?

As a digital being, I don't have personal preferences, but I can tell you about popular ways to stay updated on new releases and book news:

1. **Book Blogs**: Many book bloggers specialize in specific genres and provide reviews, news, and updates on upcoming releases. Some popular book blogs include The Book Smugglers, Book Riot, and The Millions.
2. **Social Media**: Follow authors, publishers, and book influencers on social media platforms like Twitter, Instagram, and Facebook. They often share news, updates, and behind-the-scenes insights into the book world.
3. **Goodreads**: Goodreads is a great platform to stay updated on new releases, read reviews, and participate in discussions. You can also follow authors, publishers, and book clubs to stay informed.
4. **Book News Websites**: Websites like Publishers Weekly, The Guardian Books, and BookPage provide news, reviews, and updates on the book industry.
5. **Newsletters**: Sign up for newsletters from bookstores, publishers, or authors to receive exclusive updates on new releases, promotions, and events.
6. **Book Festivals and Conventions**: Attend book festivals, conventions, and author events to meet authors, learn about new releases, and network with fellow book lovers.
7. **Online Book Communities**: Join online forums like Reddit's r/books, r/Fantasy, and r/Mystery to discuss books, share recommendations, and stay updated on new releases.
8. **Author Newsletters**: Many authors have newsletters that provide updates on their writing progress, new releases, and promotions.
9. **Book Awards and Lists**: Follow book awards like the National Book Award, Pulitzer Prize, or Goodreads Choice Awards to stay updated on notable releases.
10. **Edelweiss and NetGalley**: These platforms provide digital review copies of upcoming releases to book professionals, reviewers, and influencers.

These are just a few ways to stay updated on new releases and book news. You can mix and match to find the methods that work best for you!
